          Individual Stock Analysis
        
AAPL declined 0.30% today to $230.89, extending YTD losses to -7.80%. Apple's underperformance stems from mixed iPhone demand dynamics, with Citi noting that while 2Q25 iPhone sales exceeded consensus by 11% due to tariff-related pull-forward demand, the latest iPhone 17 build for 2H25 remains flat YoY at approximately 85M units. The company faces headwinds from Qualcomm's reduced share in upcoming iPhone models, dropping to 70% from 100% in previous launches, while global smartphone shipment growth remains modest at 0.7% for 2025E.7MSFT fell 0.59% to $517.10 but maintains strong YTD gains of 22.68%. Microsoft's performance is driven by aggressive AI infrastructure investments, with the company targeting $120B in full-year capital expenditures, representing the largest commitment among hyperscalers. The massive capex deployment, funded by strong cash flows rather than debt, positions Microsoft to capitalize on structural shifts in digital services demand and AI adoption across enterprise customers.1NVDA gained 0.86% to $182.01, delivering 35.54% YTD returns despite recent volatility. Morgan Stanley raised its price target to $206 from $200, citing "remarkable," "insatiable," and "massive" demand that continues to exceed supply constraints. The firm increased 2026 estimates to $273.2B revenue and $6.51 EPS, driven by improving supply conditions and sustained hyperscaler AI infrastructure buildouts.19AMZN edged up 0.20% to $231.49 with modest 5.52% YTD gains. Amazon's strategic expansion into same-day fresh grocery delivery across 2,300 US cities by year-end, supported by $4B infrastructure investment, aims to capture a larger share of the $940B US grocery market while integrating more customers into Prime. The company's $100B+ annual capex commitment and strong Q2 performance with 13% YoY revenue growth to $167.7B underpin analyst price targets near $265.151GOOGL declined 0.20% to $203.50 but holds 7.50% YTD gains. Alphabet increased its full-year capex forecast to $85B, while expanding strategic investments including a $1.4B backstop for TeraWulf's AI data center expansion and additional warrants for a potential 14% stake in the bitcoin miner. The company's diversified revenue streams from search, YouTube advertising, and rapidly growing Google Cloud services drive continued market share expansion.112META dropped 2.27% to $767.37 despite strong 31.06% YTD performance. Meta's momentum stems from exceptional Q2 results with $47.5B revenue (+22% YoY) and $18.3B net income (+36% YoY), while raising FY2025 capex guidance to $69B midpoint. The company's AI-driven ad targeting improvements and potential September debut of "Hypernova" glasses, combined with Instagram generating over half of US advertising revenue in 2025, support continued growth despite Reality Labs' cumulative $60B+ losses.14165AVGO fell 0.19% to $305.76 with solid 31.88% YTD gains. Broadcom benefits from the AI infrastructure boom through its semiconductor solutions for hyperscaler data centers and networking equipment. The company's exposure to the massive capex spending by Microsoft, Amazon, Google, and Meta, totaling over $344B this year, positions it as a key beneficiary of the AI revolution's hardware requirements.1CRWD declined 0.36% to $426.34 but maintains 24.60% YTD returns. CrowdStrike faces near-term headwinds with Evercore ISI lowering its price target to $425 and adding it to "Tactical Underperform" due to subdued channel checks ahead of Q2 results. However, Wedbush's inclusion in its "IVES AI 30" list reflects strong deal flow with AI module add-ons, while the company's total addressable market is projected to double to $250B by FY29 despite revenue growth deceleration.3NFLX rose 0.50% to $1,245.09, extending impressive 39.69% YTD gains. Netflix's outperformance reflects successful content strategy execution, subscriber growth momentum, and effective pricing optimization. The streaming giant benefits from its global scale advantages and content production capabilities, positioning it well in the competitive streaming landscape while maintaining pricing power through premium content offerings.NOW surged 2.86% to $892.05 despite challenging -15.85% YTD performance. ServiceNow's resilience stems from AI initiatives including a $20M Now Assist deal and 21 agreements involving five or more Now Assist products. The company's AI strategy strengthening through partnerships with NVIDIA on the Nemotron large language model and acquisitions of data.world and Logik.ai positions it for digital workflow transformation growth.4TSLA gained 1.39% to $335.16 but remains down -17.01% YTD. Tesla's struggles reflect weakening demand dynamics, with British lease costs dropping by half YoY as the company attempts to boost faltering UK sales. The EV maker faces intensifying competition and demand challenges across key markets, despite efforts to stimulate sales through aggressive pricing strategies.5PLTR fell 1.77% to $174.03 despite exceptional 130.11% YTD gains. Palantir faces pressure from Citron Research's short position, calling it "beyond overvalued" with a $40 fair value target based on 17x price-to-sales multiple applied to projected 2026 revenue of $5.6B. However, multiple analyst upgrades following strong Q2 results, including Bank of America's $180 target and Wedbush's $200 target, reflect the company's "Rule of 40" score of 94 and 93% YoY US commercial revenue growth, supported by a $10B Army contract and expanding enterprise partnerships.2
